Message.Title: Bank of America Offers to Repurchase Up to $4 Billion of Debt
Message.Msg: By Tess Stynes Bank of America Corp. (BAC) is offering to repurchase as much as $4 billion of debt as the banking giant continues efforts to reduce costs. The offer includes 16 series of debt that mature next year that are denominated in U.S. dollars, Canadian dollars, euros or Swiss Francs. The company's EUR811 million ($1.09 billion) of floating rate senior notes that mature in February have first priority. Notes must be tendered by Oct. 30 to receive the early tender payment. The offer is set to expire Nov. 14. Bank of America on Wednesday showed signs of recovering from years mired in legal woes, posting solid third-quarter earnings on a pickup in loan demand from consumers and businesses. Shares were down 12 cents at $14.44 in recent premarket trading.

Message.Title: BAC to 16.50 by year end?
Message.Msg: Honest amateur here. The upward trend charted with these lows resumes unbroken: 4/18 11.44, 6/24 12.35, and 10/9 13.69. The 1st two lows both preceded 22% jumps of 13.93 on 5/30 and 15.03 on 7/23 over 42 and 29 days. Sticking hard and fast to that pattern means BAC goes to 16.7 by mid November. The first retracement was 63%, this last retracement only 50%. You could argue that BAC should head back and make it a full 2/3 retracement before going higher which would be about 13.30. However, this seems unlikely given the strong bounce off of 13.69. All things being equal, seems like we go higher. Honest, civil arguments/discussion welcome.

Topic.Title: BAC to 16.50 by year end?

Message.Msg: Would be pleasant but no one knows. What we do know is that BofA is on a growth path and it is, one by one, solving its outstanding problems. And it is buying back a lot of shares. This means that the price of the shares will be improving over the future. But it is next to impossible to pin point a specific price at a specific date. That said, I would not be surprised to see BAC close this year at $16, plus or minus 50 cents. And close of next year could easily go over $20, especially if the dividend is increased even by a trivial amount. Best strategy is to buy and hold.

Message.Title: BAC: Expect Stock Buybacks To Accelerate In 2014
Message.Msg: In March 2013, following last year's the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review ("CCAR") process with the Fed, Bank of America (BAC) announced it had permission to buy back stock for the first time since the 2008 financial crisis. Specifically, it had Fed approval to redeem $5.5 billion of preferred shares along with approval to buy back $5 billion of common stock. The bank redeemed the preferred stock in May as part of a broader strategy of managing net interest margin by refinancing high-cost liabilities (with some of the redeemed shares paying over 8% in non-cumulative preferred dividend yield), and also in 2013 Q2 repurchased $1 billion of common shares at an average price of $12.6. With tangible book value per share at $13.3, stock buyback was a good use of capital, and this remains true even at the current stock price of $14.1. CEO Brian Moynihan has commented: buying back common shares is the best way to continue to drive value for our shareholders and, indeed, the buyback has taken precedence over raising the dividend, which remains token at 1 cents/share per quarter. Mr. Moynihan went on to observe "we have more than adequate capital to support our strategic plans" and this appears to be true; at the end of 2013Q2, the bank had top-tier common capital of $126 billion (calculated under the toughest standard of Basel 3 on a fully phased-in basis) representing 9.6% of risk-weighted assets of $1,310 billion (calculated under the same regime). Given the minimum required ratio for 2019 is 9% (being a base minimum of 7.5% plus a systemically important financial institution or SIFI buffer of 1.5%), the present excess capital is over $8 billion.

Topic.Title: BAC to 16.50 by year end?

Message.Msg: I think there's a good chance. Stock trades well below book value. But the big factor is dividends. BofA didn't ask to pay a dividend at the last stress test. Instead, they asked to buy back $5 billion in stock. Thi syear, I think they ask to pay a dividend. Consider: BofA pays 8% of earnings ($400 million) as dividend. Trailing earnings were $5 billion. But those earnings were impaired by litigation costs. BofA is expected to earn 9 billion this year. if the payout ratio stays at 8%, the dividend will nearly double. If BofA gets approved to pay say, 30% of earnings, suddenly BofA has a substantial payout. That's what will push the stock higher, imo. And I bet speculation about what BfoA will ask for starts before year end

Topic.Title: Deadbeats

Message.Msg: Here, browse thru this (from Forbes): Jerry Brown Stands Atop California's Collapsing House Of Cards SAN FRANCISCO, CA - JULY 11, 2013 Jerry Brown, soon to be California’s longest-serving Governor, is obsessed with his legacy. Legacies, however, are judged retrospectively. For now, Brown has been receiving much credit nationally for “balancing” the budget. In truth, the budget is not really balanced and Brown is setting California up to fall like a house of cards. Jerry Brown certainly is having a good year in the media. This year, PBS told us: “Gov. Jerry Brown Makes Tough Choices to Balance State Budget.” The Atlantic recently heralded: “California’s New ‘Problem’: Jerry Brown on the Sudden Surplus.” Even BusinessWeek proclaimed that Jerry Brown had “Scared California Straight” and that “Jerry Brown Stays Stern on California’s Budget Surplus.” California's Anti-Fracking Ideologues Look A Gift Horse In The Mouth Thomas Del Beccaro Thomas Del Beccaro Contributor Barack Obama: The Anti-Capital President Thomas Del Beccaro Thomas Del Beccaro Contributor In 'The Divided Era,' The U.S. Becomes England Thomas Del Beccaro Thomas Del Beccaro Contributor The New Left Only Cares About Power, Not People Thomas Del Beccaro Thomas Del Beccaro Contributor Brown has received such praise in connection with the California budget process this year, and the ruling Democrats’ self-proclaimed budget balancing. The real score in California, however, demonstrates that the budget is not really balanced and there is nothing but trouble ahead.

Message.Title: (BAC) Numbers Tweaked Higher at Evercore Partners Post Q3
Message.Msg: Evercore Partners analyst Andrew Marquardt bumped estimates up and his price target on Overweight-rated Bank of America (NYSE: BAC) from $16 to $17 following Q3 results. Marquardt notes, "'13 to $1.00 (from $0.91), '14 to $1.36 (from $1.30) '15 to $1.63 (from $1.52) as we model credit costs remaining lower for longer, have incrementally higher confidence in expense saves falling to the bottom line and see ongoing stabilization in revenue trends. P/T goes to $17 (from $16) and implies 10.4x '15 EPS ests and 1.1x '14 TBV."
